settings.title: Contact
settings.text:
hello@posteress.com

Grootzeil 107, 1034LS Amsterdam, Netherlands
Posteress is a graphic design project that explores the nature of hopes and dreams and how easily they can become illusions if influenced by socially spread imagery and projections.

settings.text:
In order to provide the best quality for art prints, Posteress started her own print house with HP's flagship Giclée printer and Hahnemühle's award-winning Bamboo paper. Each poster is hand-printed with personal quality control over the process and final product.
Posteress contributes to a sustainable use of natural resources, staying carbon-neutral to further support the environment.

Read Posteress' sustainability statement.

settings.subtitle: IN-HOUSE HANDMADE
settings.title: GICLÉE PRINTING
settings.text:
Giclée printing (from French gicler, meaning to spray) is the name for high-end inkjet printing using pigment-based archival inks. This dramatically increases the art prints' longevity, their colour variety and ultimate quality which matches the strictest museum requirements.

Posteress prints all her poster art on a HP's newest DesignJet Z9⁺, one of the best printers in the highest league of printing. Its 2400 nozzle-per-inch high-definition printheads deliver stunning results in terms of colour and sharpness. The printer has a vertical and horizontal trimmers that cut your poster perfectly on all sides.

Each poster is hand-printed, signed, numbered and packed by the artist.

settings.subtitle: HAHNEMÜHLE FINEART | MUSEUM QUALITY | SUSTAINABLE
settings.title: BAMBOO PAPER
settings.text:
Founded in 1584 as a paper mill in Germany, Hahnemühle is one of the leading Fine Art paper manufacturers.

Their Natural Line won the TIPA World Award 2020 for "Best Inkjet Photo Paper". The Bamboo paper from this line is the world’s first Fine Art inkjet paper made from the bamboo plant, the production of which requires little maintenance compared to other paper source materials. It regrows very fast, needs no pesticides, consumes little water and contributes to a sustainable approach in the use of resources.

• Highly Sustainable
• 90% bamboo fibres and 10% cotton
• 290 g/m2
• Natural white color, without optical brighteners
• Lightly textured felt structure
• Matte Premium coating
• Acid- and lignin- free
• More than 100 years age resistance

settings.subtitle: SAFE STRONG SHOCKPROOF
settings.title: PACKAGING
settings.text:
The posters are protected with silk tissue paper and shipped in triangular single corrugated cardboard tubes. These tubes have strong corners that are shock resistant and prevent your rolled-up posters from getting creased. The tube's triangular shape also makes it very easy and safe to take out the poster.The packaging is 100% recyclable.

With every order, Posteress provides a set of cotton gloves for the unpacking and handling of the poster.

settings.subtitle: Giclée Museum Quality
settings.title: IN-HOUSE PRINTING

settings.subtitle: DIGITAL ART
settings.title: GICLÉE PRINTS
settings.text: Museum quality printing using pigment-based archival inks on highly sustainable Hahnemühle Bamboo paper. Limited to 50 prints. Numbered and signed by the artist.

settings.subtitle: HAND-CRAFTED CANVAS
settings.title: MIXED MEDIA
settings.text: One of a kind handmade mixed media posters on Van Beek Premium Cotton canvases. All canvases are signed by the artist and come with a certificate of uniqueness.

settings.subtitle: MIXED MEDIA
settings.title: POSTERS ON CANVAS
settings.text: Unique hand-crafted posters created with traditional painting and drawing materials mixed with any other imaginable media

settings.subtitle: ABOUT THE artist
settings.title: WHO IS POSTERESS
settings.text: Posteress is a project by Angelina Severino, an artist and multidisciplinary designer based in Amsterdam. This project combines her love for posters with research of human desires and fantasies.

settings.subtitle: IN-HOUSE MUSEUM QUALITY
settings.title: ART PRINTS
settings.text:
Giclée printing (from French gicler, meaning to spray) is the name for high-end inkjet printing using pigment-based archival inks. The vivid colours of Giclée art prints last more than 100 years.

All the digitally created posters are printed on the Hahnemühle Fineart Bamboo paper. Its award winning quality matches the strictest museum requirements while being highly sustainable (90% bamboo fibres and 10% cotton).

Each poster is hand-printed, signed, numbered and packed by the artist.

settings.subtitle: Hand-crafted Poster Art
settings.title: SPECIAL FORMAT
settings.text:
The mixed media poster artworks are hand-finished Giclée prints on Hahnemühle Bamboo fine art paper.

Each version is unique and different in terms of the use of materials such as acrylic paint, markers, pencils, spray paint, fineliners, volcanic pumice rock, tape, etc.

This variety of materials allows poster art to expand its traditional 2D printed format and to widen the artistic possibilities of expression.

settings.title: EMAILS ARE FUN!
settings.text: Sign up to be the first to know about limited offers, new designs and more

settings.title: ABOUT THE ARTIST
settings.text:
My name is Angelina Severino, I am an artist and multidisciplinary designer based in Amsterdam. My career includes work as an Art Director in advertising agencies such as TBWA, DDB, STARCOM, and recently as a Brand Identity and Product Designer for international clients like Yamaha, Coca-Cola and a number of Dutch tech companies. 

Posteress is my personal artistic project where I research a diverse range of human phenomena – individuality, collectiveness, consciousness, feelings, imagination. Coming from years of work in advertising I have seen how our minds can be easily manipulated by attractive images and unfulfilled promises. This has inspired me to look further into the process of how hopes and dreams come to exist. Whether it is an innate process or an imposition of ideas, I believe this is a fascinating subject worth examining.

settings.subtitle: POSTER ART
settings.title: DIGITAL AND ANALOGUE
settings.text:
The poster came to existence as the possibility and need for graphic design and multiplication arose in society during the Industrial Revolution. Lithographic printing opened the doors for reproduction and established the role of the graphic designer as a multidisciplinary artist.

100 years later the poster has become accepted as an art form, finding its place next to other traditional visual arts. This is the reason I choose for limited editions and unique mixed media artworks – to treat poster art as true art. Born digitally, my posters take the shape of 50 limited edition Giclée prints and one-of-a-kind mixed media canvases.

settings.title: Inspiration
settings.text:
Having been born and raised in Russia , I take a lot of inspiration from Russian Constructivism and Soviet design.

Their brutal concrete monumentalism conjoined with sci-fi futurism reveals social and aesthetic aspects of naive, hopeful and simultaneously utopian concepts.

settings.subtitle: Grand Soviet
settings.title: Illusion
settings.text:
For decades the Soviet and Post-Soviet people have been taught to love and care for a set of ideas and beliefs that were meant to be progressive, inspiring as well as revolutionary. The revolution did happen, even if only for a brief time, before it degenerated in the betrayal of the people who quickly found themselves in a society where they are forced to find positivity in their everyday lives in order to survive.

This wish to stay positive at the face of broken hopes and dreams is an admirably strong quality in humans everywhere in the world. New desires, wishes and beliefs are born and create an uplift and new stimuli for us to move forward.

settings.subtitle: THE MEDIUM
settings.title: WHY POSTERS?
settings.text:
Poster Art has always advanced in sync with society's collective consciousness and its desires and fantasies which shaped the artists' communication and creativity under the direction of commissions. Abstracted from its initial functions such as selling goods or promoting events, the poster is a perfect format for expressing the artist's vision and fantasy. Its artistic value, communicative potential and creative freedom are unlimited.

The poster as an advertising format has practically disappeared from the streets, where it used to thrive, and moved to the web. There it transformed into animated banners, website headers and popup ads. The format of the artistic printed poster therefore becomes an artefact. Poster Art now finds its place in private homes, offices, hotels, where it retains its "art for the people" status and its advertising duties, this time around promoting art in everyday life.
